WorkerGlobalScope.summary: The WorkerGlobalScope interface of the Web Workers API is an interface representing the scope of any worker. Workers have no browsing context; this scope contains the information usually conveyed by objects â€” in this case event handlers, the console or the associated object. Each WorkerGlobalScope has its own event loop.

remarks.para: This interface is usually specialized by each worker type: for dedicated workers, for shared workers, and for ServiceWorker. The self property returns the specialized scope for each context.

-Other global object interface: , , ,
-Other Worker-related interfaces: , and
-Using web workers

WorkerGlobalScopeAtob.summary:
The atob() method of the interface decodes a
string of data which has been encoded using Base64 encoding. You can use
the method to encode and transmit
data which may otherwise cause communication problems, then transmit it and use the
atob() method to decode the data again. For example, you can encode,
transmit, and decode control characters such as ASCII values 0 through 31.

remarks.para:
-A polyfill of atob is available in core-js
-data URLs
-: the same method, but in window scopes.
-
-

WorkerGlobalScopeAtob.returns: An ASCII string containing decoded data from encodedData.

WorkerGlobalScopeBtoa.summary: The btoa() method of the interface creates a {{glossary("Base64")}}-encoded {{Glossary("ASCII")}} string from a binary string (i.e., a string in which each character in the string is treated as a byte of binary data).

remarks.para:
You can use this method to encode data which may otherwise cause communication problems, transmit it, then use the method to decode the data again.
For example, you can encode control characters such as ASCII values 0 through 31.

-A polyfill of btoa is available in core-js
-data URLs
-
-: the same method, but in window scopes.
-
-Base64

WorkerGlobalScopeBtoa.returns: An ASCII string containing the Base64 representation of stringToEncode.

WorkerGlobalScopeCaches.summary:
The caches read-only property of the interface returns the object associated with the current context.
This object enables functionality such as storing assets for offline use, and generating custom responses to requests.

remarks.para:
-Service Workers
-
-

WorkerGlobalScopeClearInterval.summary: The clearInterval() method of the interface cancels a timed, repeating action which was previously established by a call to . If the parameter provided does not identify a previously established action, this method does nothing.

WorkerGlobalScopeClearTimeout.summary: The clearTimeout() method of the interface cancels a timeout previously established by calling .

remarks.para:
If the parameter provided does not identify a previously established action,
this method does nothing.

WorkerGlobalScopeCreateImageBitmap.summary:
The createImageBitmap() method of the interface creates a bitmap from a given source, optionally cropped to contain only a portion of that source.
It accepts a variety of different image sources, and returns a {{jsxref("Promise")}} which resolves to an .
WorkerGlobalScopeCreateImageBitmap.returns: A {{jsxref("Promise")}} which resolves to an object containing bitmap data from the given rectangle.

WorkerGlobalScopeCrossOriginIsolated.summary: The crossOriginIsolated read-only property of the interface returns a boolean value that indicates whether the document is cross-origin isolated.

remarks.para:
A cross-origin isolated document only shares its Browsing context with same-origin documents in popups and navigations, and resources (both same-origin and cross-origin) that the document has opted into using via CORS (and COEP for <iframe>).
The relationship between a cross-origin opener of the document or any cross-origin popups that it opens are severed.
The document may also be hosted in a separate OS process alongside other documents with which it can communicate by operating on shared memory.
This mitigates the risk of side-channel attacks and cross-origin attacks referred to as XS-Leaks.
Cross-origin isolated documents operate with fewer restrictions when using the following APIs:
A document will be cross-origin isolated if it is returned with an HTTP response that includes the headers:

Access to the APIs must also be allowed by the Permissions-Policy Permissions-Policy/cross-origin-isolated.
Otherwise crossOriginIsolated property will return false, and the document will not be able to use the APIs listed above with reduced restrictions.

WorkerGlobalScopeCrypto.summary: The crypto read-only property of the interface returns the object for this worker. This object gives workers access to certain cryptographic related services.

remarks.para:
Although the property itself is read-only, all of its methods (and the methods of its
child object, ) are not read-only, and therefore vulnerable
to attack by polyfill.
Although crypto is available on all workers, the returned Crypto object only has one usable feature in insecure contexts: the method. In general, you should use this API only in secure contexts.

-The interface
-

WorkerGlobalScopeCrypto.value: An instance of the interface, providing access to general-purpose cryptography and a strong random-number generator.

WorkerGlobalScopeDump.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The WorkerGlobalScope.dump() method logs messages to the browser's standard output (stdout). If the browser was started from a terminal, output sent to dump() will appear in the terminal. This is the same as , but for workers.

remarks.para: Output from dump() is not sent to the browser's developer tools console. To log to the developer tools console, use console.log().

WorkerGlobalScopeError.summary: The error event of the interface fires when an error occurs in the worker.

remarks.para: The interface it belongs to.

WorkerGlobalScopeFetch.summary: The fetch() method of the interface starts the process of fetching a resource from the network, returning a promise that is fulfilled once the response is available.

remarks.para: The promise resolves to the object representing the response to your request.

A fetch() promise only rejects when the request fails, for example, because of a badly-formed request URL or a network error.
A fetch() promise does not reject if the server responds with HTTP status codes that indicate errors (404, 504, etc.).
Instead, a then() handler must check the and/or properties.
The fetch() method is controlled by the connect-src directive of Content Security Policy rather than the directive of the resources it's retrieving.

blockquote.para: The fetch() method's parameters are identical to those of the constructor.

remarks.para:
-
-Fetch API
-ServiceWorker API
-HTTP access control (CORS)
-HTTP

WorkerGlobalScopeFetch.returns: A {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves to a object.

WorkerGlobalScopeFonts.summary: The fonts property of the interface returns the interface of the worker.

remarks.para: This property is part of the CSS Font Loading API.

- interface
-

WorkerGlobalScopeFonts.value:
The returned value is the interface of the worker.
The FontFaceSet interface is useful for loading new fonts, checking the status of previously loaded fonts etc.

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGThe parameters passed to this method represent the URLs of classic scripts to be imported into a worker.
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

remarks.para:
You can mitigate this risk by having a Content Security Policy (CSP) that restricts the locations from which scripts can be loaded, and by always assigning objects instead of strings and enforcing trusted types.
See Security considerations for more information.
The importScripts() method of the interface synchronously imports one or more scripts into the scope of a classic worker (a worker constructed from a classic script).
Note that the method cannot be used in module workers, which instead load dependencies using import statements.

WorkerGlobalScopeIndexedDB.summary:
The indexedDB read-only property of the interface provides a mechanism for workers to
asynchronously access the capabilities of indexed databases.

remarks.para:
-Using IndexedDB
-Starting transactions:
-Using transactions:
-Setting a range of keys:
-Retrieving and making changes to your data:
-Using cursors:
-Reference example: To-do Notifications (View the example live).

WorkerGlobalScopeIsSecureContext.summary: The isSecureContext read-only property of the interface returns a boolean indicating whether the current context is secure (true) or not (false).

remarks.para: -Secure contexts

WorkerGlobalScopeLanguagechange.summary: The languagechange event is fired at the global scope object when the user's preferred language changes.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

WorkerGlobalScopeLocation.summary: The read-only location property of the interface returns the associated with the worker. It is a specific location object, mostly a subset of the for browsing scopes, but adapted to workers.

WorkerGlobalScopeNavigator.summary: The navigator read-only property of the interface returns the associated with the worker. It is a specific navigator object, mostly a subset of the for browsing scopes, but adapted to workers.

WorkerGlobalScopeOffline.summary: The offline event of the fires when the device loses connection to the internet.

remarks.para: The interface it belongs to.

WorkerGlobalScopeOnline.summary: The online event of the fires when the device reconnects to the internet.

remarks.para: The interface it belongs to.

WorkerGlobalScopeOrigin.summary: The origin read-only property of the interface returns the origin of the global scope, serialized as a string.

remarks.para:
-Window.origin
-origin glossary term

WorkerGlobalScopePerformance.summary: The performance property of the interface returns a object, which can be used to gather performance information about code running in the worker's scope.

remarks.para: Performance entries are per context. If you create a mark on a worker thread, you will not see it in the main thread or any other workers.
Note that only the following performance interfaces are available in worker contexts:

WorkerGlobalScopePerformance.value: A object offering access to performance and timing-related information for the context it is called on.

WorkerGlobalScopeQueueMicrotask.summary:
The queueMicrotask() method of the interface
queues a microtask to be executed at a safe time prior to control returning to the
browser's event loop.

remarks.para:
The microtask is a short function which will run after
the current task has completed its work and when there is no other code waiting to be
run before control of the execution context is returned to the browser's event loop.

This lets your code run without interfering with any other, potentially higher
priority, code that is pending, but before the browser regains control over the
execution context, potentially depending on work you need to complete. You can learn
more about how to use microtasks and why you might choose to do so in our microtask guide.

The importance of microtasks comes in its ability to perform tasks asynchronously but
in a specific order. See Using microtasks in JavaScript with queueMicrotask() for more details.

Microtasks are especially useful for libraries and frameworks that need to perform
final cleanup or other just-before-rendering tasks.

-
-Polyfill of queueMicrotask() in core-js
-Using microtasks in JavaScript with queueMicrotask()
-Asynchronous JavaScript
-queueMicrotask explainer
-Tasks, microtasks, queues and schedules by Jake Archibald

WorkerGlobalScopeRejectionhandled.summary: The rejectionhandled event is sent to the script's global scope (typically ) whenever a rejected {{jsxref("Promise")}} is handled late, i.e., when a handler is attached to the promise after its rejection had caused an event.

remarks.para: This can be used in debugging and for general application resiliency, in tandem with the unhandledrejection event, which is sent when a promise is rejected but there is no handler for the rejection at the time.

-Promise rejection events
-
-
-

WorkerGlobalScopeReportError.summary: The reportError() method of the interface may be used to report errors to the console or event handlers of global scopes, emulating an uncaught JavaScript exception.

remarks.para:
This feature is primarily intended for custom event-dispatching or callback-manipulating libraries.
Libraries can use this feature to catch errors in callback code and re-throw them to the top level handler.
This ensures that an exception in one callback will not prevent others from being handled, while at the same time ensuring that stack trace information is still readily available for debugging at the top level.
See window.reportError() for more information.

-
-
- event
- event
- event

WorkerGlobalScopeScheduler.summary: The scheduler read-only property of the interface is the entry point for using the Prioritized Task Scheduling API.

remarks.para: It returns a object instance containing and methods that can be used to schedule prioritized tasks.

-Prioritized Task Scheduling API
-
-
-
-

WorkerGlobalScopeSecuritypolicyviolation.summary: The securitypolicyviolation event is fired when a Content Security Policy is violated in a worker.

remarks.para: The handler can be assigned using the onsecuritypolicyviolation event handler property or using .

-The event of the interface
-The event of the interface
-HTTP > Content Security Policy

WorkerGlobalScopeSelf.summary: The self read-only property of the interface returns a reference to the WorkerGlobalScope itself. Most of the time it is a specific scope like , , or .
WorkerGlobalScopeSelf.value: A global scope object (differs depending on the type of worker you are dealing with, as indicated above).

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGWhen the code parameter is used, this method dynamically executes its value as JavaScript.
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site-scripting (XSS) attacks.

remarks.para:
You can mitigate this risk by always assigning objects instead of strings and enforcing trusted types.
See Security considerations in Window.setInterval() for more information.
The setInterval() method of the interface repeatedly calls a function or executes a code snippet, with a fixed time delay between each call.

It is commonly used to set a delay for functions that are executed again and again, such as animations.
You can cancel the interval using .
See for more information.
Note that if you wish to have your function called once after the specified delay, use .

-Polyfill of setInterval which allows passing arguments to the callback in core-js
-
-
-
-

WorkerGlobalScopeSetInterval.returns: A positive integer (typically within the range of 1 to 2,147,483,647) that uniquely identifies the interval timer created by the call.This identifier, often referred to as an "interval ID", can be passed to to stop the repeated execution of the specified function.

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGWhen the code parameter is used, this method dynamically executes its value as JavaScript.
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site-scripting (XSS) attacks.

remarks.para:
You can mitigate this risk by always assigning objects instead of strings and enforcing trusted types.
See Security considerations in Window.setTimeout() for more information.
The setTimeout() method of the interface sets a timer which executes a function or specified piece of code once the timer expires.

-Polyfill of setTimeout which allows passing arguments to the callback in core-js
-
-
-
-
-

WorkerGlobalScopeSetTimeout.returns:
A positive integer (typically within the range of 1 to 2,147,483,647) that uniquely identifies the timer created by the call.
This identifier, often referred to as a "timeout ID", can be passed to to cancel the timer.Within the same global environment (e.g., a specific window or worker) the timeout ID is guaranteed not to be reused for any new timer as long as the original timer remains active.
However, separate global environments maintain their own independent pools of timer IDs.

WorkerGlobalScopeStructuredClone.summary: The structuredClone() method of the interface creates a {{Glossary("deep copy")}} of a given value using the structured clone algorithm.

remarks.para:
The method also allows transferable objects in the original value to be transferred rather than cloned to the new object.
Transferred objects are detached from the original object and attached to the new object; they are no longer accessible in the original object.

-A polyfill of structuredClone is available in core-js
-Structured clone algorithm
-Structured clone polyfill

WorkerGlobalScopeStructuredClone.returns: A deep copy of the original value.

WorkerGlobalScopeTrustedTypes.summary: The trustedTypes read-only property of the interface returns the object associated with the global object, providing the entry point for using the {{domxref("Trusted Types API", "", "", "nocode")}}.

WorkerGlobalScopeUnhandledrejection.summary: The unhandledrejection event is sent to the global scope (typically ) of a script when a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that has no rejection handler is rejected.

remarks.para: This is useful for debugging and for providing fallback error handling for unexpected situations.

-Promise rejection events
-
-
- event
